entry.title: Combined summary - Modern Soft Fork Activation
entry.summary: The activation methods for soft forks in Bitcoin have been a topic of recent discussion among developers. The focus is on proposals that benefit users without negatively impacting anyone. Two strategies for locking in upgrades have been proposed, and the activation strategy focuses on keeping the network in consensus instead of relying on popularity or voting. The use of BIP 9 deployment with a one-year time horizon for activation with 95% miner readiness has been proposed as an effective way to achieve certain goals, but concerns were raised about whether the proposal had enough time for observation. A new activation method has been proposed by the Bitcoin Core development team, which includes a three-step process to ensure standard activation goals are met.The Taproot process aims to improve Bitcoin by updating its protocol and requires 95% readiness signaling from miners for activation, but if this threshold isn't met, the activation may be delayed for 2.5 years. To avoid activating in the face of significant, reasonable, and directed objection, Jeremy Rubin proposed a spork protocol upgrade model that has five interesting properties. The first property is up to miners to orphan spork-activating blocks. The second property makes it improbable/impossible for even earlier adoption. The third property makes the missing spork'd block "go away" over time, and the additional difficulty of *not activating* a rejected spork fills in as an additional PoW. Bitcoin developer Matt Corallo has proposed a set of requirements for activating soft forks in Bitcoin, which includes avoiding activation in the face of significant objection, using hashpower enforcement to de-risk the upgrade process, and following the will of the community. He also suggests that having a supermajority of miners enforce the new rules can bridge the gap in time between activation and adoption. The conversation on the bitcoin-dev mailing list discussed the ideal percentage of miners needed to upgrade to a new set of rules, with some suggesting a 90% threshold, but achieving 95% can prove challenging due to negligent miners forgetting to upgrade.The proposed activation methods aim to achieve several goals, including readiness by miners, measurement, and community engagement. BIP 9 has been proposed as an effective way to achieve some of these goals, but it fails to achieve others. BIP 8 has been proposed as an alternative, but it also fails to meet certain requirements. The Great Consensus Cleanup softfork proposal suggests a standard BIP 9 deployment with a one-year time horizon for activation and a consensus rule requiring blocks to signal for activation in the last activation window. The Bitcoin Core development team has proposed a three-step process for future soft fork activation.The author of another post discusses the best way to deploy a soft fork in Bitcoin while balancing several critical goals. They suggest that achieving high levels of community engagement is crucial for successful deployment. The focus should be on resolving any reasonable technical objections rather than who has the most money/power/hashpower/nodes/reddit-accounts. Overall, the goal is to prevent a small malicious minority from delaying activation, and achieving high levels of community engagement is crucial for successful deployment. The author encourages users to consider how they can resist unwanted changes effectively, which could lead to a more decentralized and constructive Bitcoin community.
